verses.text: There is an evil that I have seen under the sun, and it lies heavy upon mankind:
verses.comment: The phrase 'under the sun' is used throughout Ecclesiastes to emphasize the earthly, temporal viewpoint compared to the eternal. This sets the stage for a reflection on the fleeting nature of worldly pursuits.

verses.text: A man to whom God gives riches, possessions, and honor, so that he lacks nothing of all he desires, yet God does not permit him to enjoy them, but a stranger enjoys them. This is vanity; it is a grievous affliction.
verses.comment: Here, the text highlights the limits of earthly blessings apart from God’s purpose, reflecting humanity’s need for a deeper inheritance beyond material wealth. The passive allowance by God hints at divine providence and mystery in worldly affairs.

verses.text: If a man fathers a hundred children and lives many years, so that the days of his years are many, but his soul is not satisfied with life’s good things, and he has no burial, I say that a stillborn child is better off than he.
verses.comment: The loss of burial rites was seen as a disgrace in ancient Israel, emphasizing the importance of both physical and spiritual fulfillment. It subtly points toward the necessity of community and proper rites, prefiguring sacramental care.

verses.text: For it comes in vanity and goes in darkness, and in darkness its name is covered.
verses.comment: Spiritual darkness and anonymity highlight the consequences of a life separated from true purpose. The literal meaning refers to obscurity, the spiritual points toward the human need for meaning found in God’s plan.

verses.text: Moreover, it has not seen the sun or known anything, yet it finds rest rather than he.
verses.comment: ‘Rest’ here gives a spiritual undertone, paralleling the hope of the righteous for ultimate peace beyond earthly toil—anticipating the rest offered in Christ (Matthew 11:28).

verses.text: Even if he should live a thousand years twice over, yet enjoy no good—do not all go to the same place?
verses.comment: The destination refers to Sheol, the place of the dead (see Genesis 3:19), which highlights the universal destiny of all people and the futility of merely extending earthly life. It leads to reflection on the hope of resurrection.

verses.text: All the toil of man is for his mouth, yet his appetite is never satisfied.
verses.comment: Human longing is insatiable by material means, indicating the deeper hunger for God and spiritual fulfillment. This lays a foundation for New Testament teachings on the Bread of Life (John 6:35).

verses.text: For what advantage has the wise man over the fool? And what does the poor man gain who knows how to conduct himself before the living?
verses.comment: Earthly wisdom and social skill are ultimately limited in securing true happiness. This echoes the necessity of more than human wisdom: the need for revelation and grace.

verses.text: Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the appetite. This also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
verses.comment: There is a call here to contentment, but also the warning that mere satisfaction in earthly things is not enough. Spiritual longing for more points toward the promise of fulfillment beyond this life.

verses.text: Whatever has come to be has already been named, and it is known what man is, and that he is not able to dispute with One stronger than he.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over creation is emphasized, with a subtle note of submission to divine authority. This anticipates the need for humility before God and trust in the divine will.

verses.text: The more words, the more vanity, and what is the advantage to man?
verses.comment: Echoing earlier chapters, the text warns against empty speech and self-reliance. This spiritually suggests the need for guidance through revelation, authority, and tradition.

verses.text: For who knows what is good for a man in life, all the days of his fleeting life which he passes like a shadow? For who can tell him what will be after him under the sun?
verses.comment: The uncertainty of life pushes the reader to seek answers beyond himself—suggesting the necessity of authoritative guidance and hope in divine revelation, which finds its fullness in Christ and the community He establishes.
